page.title: 09THE VILLAGE OF BURITON
page.content: { {Local History:}This village (pop.464) is a typical spring-line settlement situated at the base of the South Downs. The springs still feed the Wooliff Pond and the Village Pond. It is uncertain when the village was founded but field systems, encampments burial mounds, Roman villa sites and sunken lanes suggest a continuous community since Neolithic times. The church was built in the 11th Century but the 'burh' in Buriton suggests a Saxon origin. {Population:}The population varied through the centuries, but once agriculture was based on the yeoman farmers and cottagers, new farmhouses were built and the village expanded. After the 17th Century only existing buildings were replaced or subdivided.{ {}
